Question_1.Context: In the study, three new GRPR-antagonist radioligands were designed and evaluated for their potential in prostate cancer treatment. The stability and uptake of these radioligands were assessed in various experiments.
Question_1.Question: What was the purpose of designing three new GRPR-antagonist radioligands in the study?
Question_1.A: To assess the metabolic stability of radioligands
Question_1.B: To evaluate the GRPR-specific uptake in PC-3 cells
Question_1.C: To investigate the biodistribution profiles of the radioligands
Question_1.D: To determine the therapeutic efficacy of the radioligands
Question_1.Source: The three new GRPR-antagonist radioligands were designed to accommodate trivalent radiometals for theranostic use, aiming to assess their biodistribution profiles.

Question_2.Context: The radioligands displayed high and GRPR-specific uptake in PC-3 cells during the in vitro assays. The GRPR-specificity was confirmed through blocking experiments.
Question_2.Question: How was the GRPR-specificity of the radioligands confirmed in the study?
Question_2.A: By evaluating the receptor affinity and binding kinetics
Question_2.B: By assessing the metabolic stability in peripheral blood
Question_2.C: By measuring the cell-associated activity in the presence of a GRPR blocker
Question_2.D: By analyzing the biodistribution profiles in PC-3 xenograft-bearing mice
Question_2.Source: The radiotracers displayed high cellular association, which was clearly GRPR-driven. The GRPR-specificity was confirmed through blocking experiments using an excess of a GRPR antagonist.

Question_3.Context: The equilibrium dissociation constants (KD) of the radioligands were determined by fitting the data to a 1:2 binding site model. Different dissociation constants were observed for the radioligands.
Question_3.Question: How were the equilibrium dissociation constants (KD) determined for the radioligands in the study?
Question_3.A: By measuring the metabolic stability in peripheral blood
Question_3.B: By evaluating the receptor affinity and binding kinetics
Question_3.C: By analyzing the biodistribution profiles in PC-3 xenograft-bearing mice
Question_3.D: By assessing the cell-associated activity in PC-3 cells
Question_3.Source: The equilibrium dissociation constants (KD) were determined by fitting the data to a 1:2 binding site model, providing insights into the receptor affinity and binding kinetics of the radioligands.

Question_4.Context: The radioligands were tested for their metabolic stability in mice peripheral blood. The stability of the radioligands was compared between control groups and groups treated with NEP-inhibitors.
Question_4.Question: How was the metabolic stability of the radioligands assessed in the study?
Question_4.A: By measuring the cell-associated activity in PC-3 cells
Question_4.B: By evaluating the receptor affinity and binding kinetics
Question_4.C: By analyzing the biodistribution profiles in PC-3 xenograft-bearing mice
Question_4.D: By analyzing the radioligands in mice blood collected post-injection
Question_4.Source: The metabolic stability of the radioligands was tested by HPLC analysis of mice blood collected post-injection, comparing stability between control groups and groups treated with NEP-inhibitors.

Question_5.Context: The biodistribution profiles of the radioligands were compared at 4 hours post-injection in PC-3 xenograft-bearing mice. Differences in tumor uptake and organ distribution were observed among the radioligands.
Question_5.Question: What was the main difference observed in the biodistribution profiles of the radioligands at 4 hours post-injection?
Question_5.A: Higher kidney uptake in one of the radioligands
Question_5.B: Lower tumor uptake in one of the radioligands
Question_5.C: Higher pancreas uptake in one of the radioligands
Question_5.D: Lower liver uptake in one of the radioligands
Question_5.Source: Among the three radioligands, [111In]In-AU-SAR-M2 showed the highest uptake in small intestines and pancreas, both GRPR-rich organs, most probably as a result of its higher GRPR-affinity.

Question_6.Context: The radioligands were further assessed for their biodistribution at 24 hours post-injection to evaluate the retention and clearance patterns. Changes in uptake and ratios were observed over time.
Question_6.Question: What change was observed in the tumor-to-kidney ratio of [111In]In-AU-SAR-M1 between 4 and 24 hours post-injection?
Question_6.Source: The tumor-to-kidney ratios for [111In]In-AU-SAR-M1 were 3.6 at 4 hours post-injection and 2.7 at 24 hours post-injection, indicating an increased ratio over time.

Question_7.Context: The study highlighted the potential of [111In]In-AU-SAR-M1 as a promising diagnostic tool for prostate cancer treatment. The radioligand demonstrated high tumor uptake and clear background in imaging experiments.
Question_7.Question: What was the key finding regarding the potential of [111In]In-AU-SAR-M1 in the study?
Question_7.C: Clear background and tumor uptake in imaging
Question_7.Source: The study indicated that [111In]In-AU-SAR-M1 showed high tumor uptake and clear background in imaging experiments, suggesting its potential as a diagnostic tool for prostate cancer.

Question_8.Context: The study emphasized the importance of NEP-inhibition in enhancing the stability and therapeutic potential of the radioligands. NEP-inhibition was achieved using a well-characterized drug.
Question_8.Question: How was NEP-inhibition induced in the study to enhance the stability of the radioligands?
Question_8.A: By modifying the structure of the radioligands
Question_8.B: By adjusting the injected peptide dose
Question_8.D: By treating animals with a NEP-inhibitor drug like Entresto®
Question_8.Source: The in situ stabilization of the radioligand in the blood-stream using Entresto® was expected to further upgrade the biodistribution profile of [111In]In-AU-SAR-M1 and possibly its theranostic partner [177Lu]Lu-AU-SAR-M1 as well.

Question_9.Context: The study discussed the potential of [111In]In-AU-SAR-M1 as a diagnostic tool for prostate cancer. The radioligand demonstrated high tumor uptake and clear background in imaging experiments.
Question_9.Question: What was the main advantage of [111In]In-AU-SAR-M1 as highlighted in the study?
Question_9.C: Clear background and tumor uptake in imaging
Question_9.Source: The study indicated that [111In]In-AU-SAR-M1 showed high tumor uptake and clear background in imaging experiments, suggesting its potential as a diagnostic tool for prostate cancer.

Question_10.Context: The study emphasized the importance of NEP-inhibition in enhancing the stability and therapeutic potential of the radioligands. NEP-inhibition was achieved using a well-characterized drug.
Question_10.Question: What potential benefits were associated with NEP-inhibition in the study?
Question_10.A: Enhanced stability and tumor uptake of the radioligands
Question_10.B: Increased liver uptake and retention of the radioligands
Question_10.C: Reduced tumor uptake and retention of the radioligands
Question_10.D: Improved kidney uptake and retention of the radioligands
Question_10.Source: The study indicated that NEP-inhibition using a well-characterized drug like Entresto® was expected to enhance the stability and tumor-targeting capabilities of the radioligands, potentially improving their therapeutic potential.
